content.text: Acute onset of paralytic disease from the botulina toxin produced by Clostridium botulinum and, less often, by C. baratii or C. butyricum. All are spore-forming anaerobic gram-positive rods. C. botulinum toxin is the world's most deadly toxin: 1 gm could kill 1 million people.
Five pathogenetic pathways to clinical botulism

items: Ingestion of preformed toxin causes food-borne botulism.
Infant botulism results from ingestion of spores that germinate in the intestinal tract. Although rare, a similar pathogenesis can occur in adults (Emerg Infect Dis 18:1, 2012).
Wound botulism results from spores deposited in wounds. Can be recurrent in injection drug users (Clin Infect Dis 52:862, 2011).
Adult enteric infectious botulism: similar to infant botulism. Toxin produced in the GI tract of the adult.
Inhalational botulism: aerosolization as in an act of bioterrorism.

content.text: Clinical syndrome is the same whether toxin is ingested, inhaled or injected. Toxin results in acute onset of bilateral cranial nerve palsies and descending symmetrical weakness.

diagnosticTestData.name: Mouse bioassay
diagnosticTestData.sampleType: Patient's serum, suspect toxin source food, or tissue from wound debridement

diagnosticTestData.name: Electromyography (EMG)
diagnosticTestData.interpretation: Helpful in experienced hands: findings include neuromuscular junction blockage, normal axonal conduction, and potentiation with rapid repetitive stimulation. CSF findings are normal.

regimenData.notes: Obtain from State Health Department or contact CDC +1 404-639-2206 or +1 770-488-7100. Can give laxatives, enemas or other cathartics if no ileus present. Monitor vital capacity. May require mechanical ventilation.
Unproven benefit. If penicillin-allergic, use Metronidazole.

procedureData.name: Surgical debridement of wound
procedureData.notes: Even if the wound appears benign.

regimenData.notes: Call +1-510-231-7600. Do not use equine antitoxin for infants. Obtain from California Infant Botulism Treatment and Prevention Program, http://www.infantbotulism.org/. Antibiotics not recommended.
